title: Is Biden’s National Daycare Good for Children?
sub_head: The Biden administration’s plan to expand child care isn’t compulsory. It will help families, help employers get stable workers and help our children.
body:
Regarding J.D. Vance and Jenet Erickson’s “Biden’s Daycare Plan Is Bad for Families” (op-ed, May 4): Attacks on advocacy for expanding availability and accessibility to developmentally supportive child care for America’s children are mind boggling. The authors point to a Canadian study written by economists instead of looking to U.S. research by those who study child development and education. As a parent and pastor who values the foundation my university-educated children received attending a state-licensed child-care center, I don’t look to economists for child-development expertise.
As a community member I have come alongside low-income working families to help them apply for child-care programs sponsored by federal and state governments, only to find out there are not nearly enough spots to meet demand, transportation is often an obstacle and the half-day program offered doesn’t help parents who are at work all day.
Less than half of eligible children have access to pre-K programs in their communities. Longitudinal studies point to the value and effectiveness in quality early childhood education to affect children’s cognitive, emotional and social development. I have personally helped families transition their young children from a neighbor’s apartment where they were watching television for hours on end while their parents were at work, to child-care classrooms where they are engaged in developmentally appropriate care.
The Biden administration’s plan to expand child care isn’t compulsory. It will help families, help employers get stable workers and help our children.
Pam Strader
